linesOfText.text: For J Â & C, with all my love

Julia was at school one afternoon and was so excited for recess.
She was not sure what to play. She might use the sidewalk chalk,
go on the slides, or swing from the monkey bars.

At recess, Julia saw some of the girls from her class at
the sandbox and decided to join them. When she walked over,
she noticed one of the girls looking at her in a funny way.

Her classmate said, âYou canât play here unless your
fingernails are painted. We all have nail polish on
and you need to have some if you want to join our club.
We look the prettiest.â

Julia was confused and her feelings were hurt.
She never thought about wearing nail polish
to school and decided to ask her mom about it
when she got home.

That afternoon, when she
jumped off the bus, Julia
immediately asked her mom,
âCan I paint my nails
this afternoon?â

Her mom said, âJulia, Iâm
surprised youâre asking for
nail polish. Weâve never
painted your nails for school
before. Why are you
thinking about it?â

Julia told her mom that one of
the girls at school said she
needed to polish her nails in
order to look pretty and play
in the sandbox. Juliaâs mom
had that funny look on her
face like she was getting
ready for a serious talk.

âJulia,â she said, âyou donât need
to look a certain way to play on
the playground. You can join in
any game you want. If those
girls are being bossy and not
being kind, then find someone
else to play with. Real friends
donât treat each other that way.â
This gave Julia something
to think about.

The next morning, Julia was
getting dressed for school. She
had a nervous feeling in her
stomach. She picked out one of
her fanciest dresses, studied
herself in the mirror, and thought,
âHmmm... do I look pretty?â
Julia looked closely at her hair,
her eyes, and her smile. She
wanted everyone at
school to
think she
looked pretty.

Julia loved the way her blue
polka dot dress looked with
her green shorts but she wanted
to add some finishing touches.
Julia tied a yellow bandana in
her hair to keep her bangs out of
her face. Then she attached a
furry tail to the back of her
dress because sometimes
she liked to pretend
she was a kitten.

Julia wondered if her friends at
school would think she was fancy.
Julia walked downstairs for
breakfast and asked her mother,
âMom, do I look pretty?â

As her mom was busy pouring
cereal and blueberries into a bowl
for Juliaâs breakfast, she said,
âJulia, I am really proud of the
way you got dressed all by
yourself. Did you wash your
hands and face? Did you brush
your teeth?â

âYes, Mommy,â Julia answered.

After breakfast, Julia was putting
her shoes and coat on to get
ready for school. She asked again,
âMom, do I look pretty?â

Her mom was putting food into Juliaâs
lunchbox and answered, âJulia, no one
has a style quite like you!â

Julia was frustrated because her mom
had not answered her question.
Julia wondered if she should change
into her purple dress instead.

On the way out the door, Julia
asked her mom again using a
louder voice, âMommy, am I
pretty?â This time, her mom bent
down and looked Julia in the eyes.

She said, âJulia, you're pretty
smart. You figured out how to
play that new math game and
even taught me how to play.â

âAnd you are pretty strong. Remember
when you helped Daddy clean up
the yard and you put all the
chairs away by yourself?â

âAnd pretty kind.
You are always so
generous with
your brother and share
your special treats.â

âAnd pretty brave.
Who went upstairs
all by herself in
the dark to get her socks?â
Julia giggled.

âAnd pretty
amazing.
I love
everything
about you.â

âBut âprettyâ is
too small a word to
describe you. You will
always be so much
more than pretty.â
The End.
